facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 503 to 506 of 1958 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 503 to 506 of 1958. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and orders dated August 4, 1957 of Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 29 to 32 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 4, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Letters patent Appeals Nos. 29 to 32, of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 29, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-When a lessee takes lease of open land for the purpose

facts.text: Appellants brought four suits in City Civil Courts, Bombay for recovery of arrears of rent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant brought these four suits in the City Civil Courts, Bombay, for recovery of arrears of rent in respect of the premises mentioned in the plaint of these several suits.

facts.text: Plaintiff stated in plaint that Bombay Rents Act does not apply to demised premises.

anchor.surface_text: For this reason the plaintiff stated in the plaint itself that this Rent Act did not apply to the demised premises.

facts.text: Defendant pleaded that Rent Act applies and City Civil Court has no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant in each case pleaded on the contrary that the Rent Act applied and so the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction to try the suits.

facts.text: Trial court held Part II of Rent Act applies, ordered return of plaints.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held that Part II of the Rent Act applied to the premises in each of these suits and consequently only the special court, specified in s. 28 of the Rent Act had jurisdiction

facts.text: Appeals to Bombay High Court summarily dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff appealed to the High Court of Bombay but all the four appeals were summarily dismissed.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeals in Bombay High Court summarily dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent appeals preferred by the plaintiff from the decision of the Single Judge were also dismissed summarily.

facts.text: Land not being used for agricultural purposes, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is undisputed in these cases that the land in respect of which the suits were brought was not being used for agricultural purposes and so comes within the definition of Premises in s. 5.

facts.text: Four premises within city of Bombay, in area specified in Schedule 1.

anchor.surface_text: The four premises in respect of which the four suits were brought are all within the city of Bombay and thus in the area specified in Schedule of the Act.

facts.text: Lease provides lessee will construct buildings suitable for residential, business, industrial or office purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The lease mentions that the lessee will construct buildings suitable for residential, business, industrial or office purposes.

facts.text: Plaintiff contended open land not let for residence or business.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that as open land is not intended to be used as it is for residence or business but for construction of buildings for residence or business the land is not being let for residence or business.

facts.text: Defendant contended letting was for residence or business as ultimate purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant in each case contends that the letting was for residence or business as that was the ultimate purpose of taking the lease.

facts.text: Supreme Court held premises let for residence/business, Part II of Rent Act applies.

anchor.surface_text: The premises let are therefore premises to which under s. 6(1) of the Rent Act the provision of part II of the Act, apply.

facts.text: City Civil Court has no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had no jurisdiction to try the suits.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are accordingly dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Vinayak Gopal v. Laxman Kashinath held land leased for construction of buildings for residence is let for residence.

anchor.surface_text: In that case the Bombay High Court held that where land is leased for the purpose of construction of buildings for residence the land is let for residence within the meaning of s. 6 of the Rent Act.

facts.text: No notification under provisos of Section 6 affecting premises.

anchor.surface_text: As there has been no notification under these provisos affecting the premises in suit, we are not concerned with them nor are we concerned with sub-s. 1A

facts.text: First issue in suits was whether court had jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The first issue framed in each of these suits therefore was, whether the Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 4, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Letters patent Appeals Nos. 29 to 32, of 1957.

It is clear under the law that the City Civil Court, Bombay, would have no jurisdiction to try these suits if the provisions of Part II of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 Bom. 57 of 1947 , which later in this judgment we shall refer to as the Rent Act, applied to the permises in suits.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 with which this Part II opens provides in its first sub- section that this part shall apply to premises let for residence, education, business, trade or storage in areas specified in Sch. 1. It is subject to a proviso that the State Government may direct that in any of the said areas, this Part shall cease to apply to premises let for any of the said purposes, with a further proviso that the State Government may again direct that in any of the said areas this Part shall re-apply to premises let for such of the, aforesaid purposes.

concepts.interpretation: Open land leased for constructing buildings intended for residence or business is 'let for residence or business'; Part II applies irrespective of whether purpose achieved with or without construction.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent appeals preferred by the plaintiff from the decision of the Single Judge were also dismissed summarily. These appeals have been preferred against that decision of the Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeals on special leave obtained from this Court.

issues.text: whether the Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: The first issue framed in each of these suits therefore was, whether the Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit. The learned Judge held that Part II of the Rent Act applied to the premises in each of these suits and consequently only the special court,

issues.text: When a lessee takes lease of open land for the purpose of constructing on it buildings intended to be used for residence or for business is this letting for residence, or letting for business?

anchor.surface_text: When a lessee takes lease of open land for the purpose of constructing on it buildings intended to be used for residence or for business is this letting for residence,, or letting for business? That is the short question which arises for decision in these four appeals. The appellant brought these

issues.text: whether it was let for residence or for education, business, trade or storage

anchor.surface_text: in the area specified in Schedule of the Act. In each of these cases we have therefore to examine the, purpose of the lease and to decide whether it was let for residence or for education, business, trade or storage. The lease men- tions that the leasee will companystruct buildings suitable for residential,

issues.text: whether when open land is being leased not to be used for residence in its condition of open land but to be used for the purpose of residence after constructing buildings thereon, the letting of the open land can reasonably be called to be letting for residence

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion,, no substance in this contention. It is quite clear that open land as it is can be used for residence and so there is no reason to think that open land was not intended to be included in 'premises' when s. 6 speaks of premises being let for residence. The more substantial question for consideration is whether when open land is being leased not to be used for residence in its condition of open land but to be used for the purpose of residence after constructing buildings thereon, the letting of the open land can reasonably be called to be letting for residence.

issues.text: whether if there is no contract to the contrary, s. 15 will really stand in the way of a lessee of the land letting out buildings constructed by him, on such land

anchor.surface_text: the probability of such difficulty in some cases, cannot be no reason to cut down the ordinary and reasonable connotation of the words 'let for residence' in s. 6. It is unnecessary for us to decide whether if there is no contract to the contrary, s. 15 will really stand in the way of a lessee of the land letting out buildings constructed by him, on such land.

arguments.claim: s.6 includes lettings of open land for specified purposes irrespective of whether achieved with or without construction

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, no substance in this contention. It is quite clear that open land as it is can be used for residence and so there is no reason to think that open land was not intended to be included in 'premises' when s. 6 speaks of premises being let for residence.

arguments.claim: s.15 bar operates on land, not on buildings constructed; does not affect s.6 interpretation

anchor.surface_text: We may say however that there is in our opinion much force in the argument which found favour with the Bombay High Court in Vinayak Gopal v. Laxman Kashinath, where the very question which is now before us arose for decision, that the bar of s. 15 will operate only in the way of letting out the land of which lease has been taken, but will not stand in the way of letting the building constructed on the land.

holdings.text: Open land as it is can be used for residence and there is no reason to think that open land was not intended to be included in 'premises' when s. 6 speaks of premises being let for residence.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion,, no substance in this contention. It is quite clear that open land as it is can be used for residence and so there is no reason to think that open land was not intended to be included in 'premises' when s. 6 speaks of premises being let for residence. The more substantial question for consideration is whether when open land is being leased not to be used for residence in its condition of open land but to be used for the purpose of residence after constructing buildings thereon, the letting of the open land can reasonably be called to be letting for residence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary use of open land for residence; no repugnancy in context to exclude from definition.

holdings.text: The words 'let for residence, education, business, trade or storage' are wide enough to include a letting for the achievement of these purposes with construction of buildings as also without construction of buildings.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. Land can be used for many purposes... In our opinion, the words 'let for residence, education, business, trade or storage are wide enough to include a letting for the achievement of these purposes with construction of buildings as also without construction of buildings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature included open land in premises and specified purposes irrespective of construction; ordinary language usage considers ultimate purpose.

holdings.text: The probability of such difficulty in some cases cannot be a reason to cut down the ordinary and reasonable connotation of the words 'let for residence' in s. 6.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that there may be cases where the contract of lease does not contain any such term and assuming further that it will not be lawful for the lessee of the land to let out the building constructed by him, the probability of such difficulty in some cases, cannot be a reason to cut down the ordinary and reasonable connotation of the words 'let for residence' in s. 6.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.15(1) subject to contract; potential subletting issues do not override plain meaning of s.6.

holdings.text: The premises let are therefore premises to which under s. 6(1) of the Rent Act the provision of part II of the Act, apply.

anchor.surface_text: The premises let are therefore premises to which under s. 6(1) of the Rent Act the provision of part II of the Act, apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease purpose for constructing buildings for residential/business purposes falls within s.6(1).

holdings.text: The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had no jurisdiction to try the suits.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had no jurisdiction to try the suits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Part II applies per s.6(1) and s.28 vests exclusive jurisdiction in special court.

holdings.text: The conclusion reached by the Bombay High Court in Vinayak Gopal's Case is, in our opinion, correct.

anchor.surface_text: We think it unnecessary however to examine whether all the reasons given in the judgment are correct. For, as already indicated, the words let for residence on a proper construction would cover the case of open land being let for construction of residential buildings and so the conclusion reached by the Bombay High Court in Vinayak Gopal's Case is, in our opinion, correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Own construction of s.6 aligns with HC conclusion; no need to scrutinize reasons.

holdings.text: There is in our opinion much force in the argument... that the bar of s. 15 will operate only in the way of letting out the land of which lease has been taken, but will not stand in the way of letting the building constructed on the land.

anchor.surface_text: We may say however that there is in our opinion much force in the argument which found favour with the Bombay High Court in Vinayak Gopal v. Laxman Kashinath, where the very question which is now before us arose for decision, that the bar of s. 15 will operate only in the way of letting out the land of which lease has been taken, but will not stand in the way of letting the building constructed on the land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide s.15 application; but persuasive that it applies to land not buildings.

holdings.text: The appeals are accordingly dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are accordingly dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No jurisdiction in City Civil Court; lower courts correct.

edges.explanation: Holding that open land as it is can be used for residence and is included in premises directly addresses the issue of whether open land leased for post-construction residence qualifies, sharing exact span.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion,, no substance in this contention. It is quite clear that open land as it is can be used for residence and so there is no reason to think that open land was not intended to be included in 'premises' when s. 6 speaks of premises being let for residence. The more substantial question for consideration is whether when open land is being leased not to be used for residence in its condition of open land but to be used for the purpose of residence after constructing buildings thereon, the letting of the open land can reasonably be called to be letting for residence.
The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had numberjurisdiction to try the suits. The appeals are accordingly dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. Land can be used for many purposes... In our opinion, the words 'let for residence, education, business, trade or storage are wide enough to include a letting for the achievement of these purposes with construction of buildings as also without construction of buildings.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had numberjurisdiction to try the suits. The appeals are accordingly dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding refusing to cut down ordinary meaning of 'let for residence' due to potential difficulties supports the broad interpretation including construction in prior holding.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that there may be cases where the contract of lease does not contain any such term and assuming further that it will not be lawful for the lessee of the land to let out the building constructed by him, the probability of such difficulty in some cases, cannot be a reason to cut down the ordinary and reasonable connotation of the words 'let for residence' in s. 6.
The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had numberjurisdiction to try the suits. The appeals are accordingly dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We may say however that there is in our opinion much force in the argument which found favour with the Bombay High Court in Vinayak Gopal v. Laxman Kashinath, where the very question which is now before us arose for decision, that the bar of s. 15 will operate only in the way of letting out the land of which lease has been taken, but will not stand in the way of letting the building constructed on the land.
The Trial Court and the High Court were therefore right in holding that the City Civil Court Bombay, had numberjurisdiction to try the suits. The appeals are accordingly dismissed with companyts.
